body:
is there any significant performance difference for computeCount true vs false  ? 
wondering if we really need to make the count configurable or can we make the counts always on.
@fjy Well, I can try make them truly extendable. Like introduce interfaces in appropriate module (druid-api? druid-processing?) and change existing implementations. Or what do you mean?

It might be useful to put a comment on the deprecated function deleteDataSource to say that
it's only the part for kill != null that's deprecated.  If the whole function were removed, there'd be no support for the endpoint "DELETE /druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}" (with no parameters).
good improvements ...

Addressed your comments, thanks @rasahner !
@fjy @gianm Could you please also take a look?
/partial/time should never used in druid, it is just a default name that is replaced
look at ServerManager

wait/time is about how long a segment waits in queue to be scanned

partial/time is used by realtimeplumber around time to scan each partial segment

but even that should be overwritten

might be good to remove default name and force an override
@fjy i have some logs that contains that metric, so i am not sure what you mean by overwritten ?
:+1: after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2533#discussion_r54302178 and conflicts are resolved.
need more deeper inspection. closing for now.

If so then I'm :+1:

``` json
2016-02-24T01:43:07,293 INFO [topN_svctrace_[2016-02-24T01:00:00.000Z/2016-02-24T02:00:00.000Z]] com.metamx.emitter.core.LoggingEmitter - Event [{"feed":"metrics","timestamp":"2016-02-24T01:43:07.293Z","service":"druid/middlemanager","host”:”indexer0004.xxx.xxxxxx.com:8100","metric":"query/wait/time","value":1,"dataSource":"svctrace","dimension":"dp","duration":"PT3600S","hasFilters":"true","id":"68efded4-b281-4a47-8531-a9e2921b50c5","interval":["2016-02-24T01:00:00.000Z/2016-02-24T02:00:00.000Z"],"numComplexMetrics":"0","numMetrics":"3","threshold":"1000","type":"topN"}]

```

@drcrallen I haven't gone through #2525 completely, but that is a dedicated aggregator for indexing and computing variance while the change proposed here is general feature to compute any polynomial function on the input. #2090 provides the expression language for computing those functions and as a result a pre-requisite.
@fjy language introduced in this PR is not directly usable, it will be made availble to druid queries via https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1965 and the doc for same will also appear there.

This is ready to be merged.

will rework test

@himanshug Fixed.
1. docs updated as you said
2. (nealy) runnable examples are added

And as explained above, not using the full schema directly is meant to support partital reading.
@fjy Addressed precious comments from @nishantmonu51 but I'm not sure I've covered whole cases.

@fjy I think I've mentioned once in first conference call. We need a map type value to be stored in druid to handle parameter values from various machines in manufacturing, but it's not supported. This is rather a hacky way to address the requirements. 

Let's assume that there is an input event from kafka, containing a map type value,

```
{
  'timestamp'='2016-01-01 ~~',
  'lot_id'='xxxx',
  'machine_id'='yyyy',
  'parameter'={'pkey1'='value1', 'pkey2'='value2'}
}
```

We can store `parameter` as two separate dimensions (`pkey` and `pvalue` in this example),

```
{
  'timestamp'='2016-01-01 ~~',
  'lot_id'='xxxx',
  'machine_id'='yyyy',
  'pkey'=['pkey1', 'pkey2'],
  'pvalue'=['value1', 'value2']
}
```

What we want to do with above is
1. using bitmapindex for `pkey` to access `pvalue`
2. retrieving it as a map if needed just like original input event

With a definition something like below(we can think `outputName` as a name of virtual column),

```
 "virtualColumns" : [ {
    "type" : "map",
    "keyDimension" : "pkey",
    "valueDimension" : "pvalue",
    "outputName" : "params"
  } ],
```

for case1, we can select `params.pkey1` to access `value1` and `params.pkey2` to access `value2`
for case2, we can select `params` to access whole `{'pkey1'='value1', 'pkey2'='value2'}`

I'm really bad at explaing something. Welcome any kind of comments or questions.
Ah, I've forgot that #2541 is a prerequisite to use this properly.
@nishantmonu51 I'll try.
@nishantmonu51 I couldn't see any differences by on/off of count from querying to two segments of 300K rows each. Should it be always on?
I think we can always turn it on and remove the flag and conditional checks for count since it doesnt affect performance at all, @fjy what is your opinion on this ?
@drcrallen can you please take look at this one it is sort of easy to pull in.
@fjy I am still working on it, I will resolve the conflicts when it is reviewable

```
new MetricsEmittingQueryRunner<T>(
                emitter,
                builderFn,
                new BySegmentQueryRunner<T>(
                    adapter.getIdentifier(),
                    adapter.getDataInterval().getStart(),
                    new CachingQueryRunner<T>(
                        adapter.getIdentifier(),
                        segmentDescriptor,
                        objectMapper,
                        cache,
                        toolChest,
                        new MetricsEmittingQueryRunner<T>(
                            emitter,
                            new Function<Query<T>, ServiceMetricEvent.Builder>()
                            {
                              @Override
                              public ServiceMetricEvent.Builder apply(@Nullable final Query<T> input)
                              {
                                return toolChest.makeMetricBuilder(input);
                              }
                            },
                            new ReferenceCountingSegmentQueryRunner<T>(factory, adapter, segmentDescriptor),
                            "query/segment/time",
                            ImmutableMap.of("segment", adapter.getIdentifier())
                        ),
                        cachingExec,
                        cacheConfig
                    )
                ),
                "query/segmentAndCache/time",
                ImmutableMap.of("segment", adapter.getIdentifier())
            ).withWaitMeasuredFromNow()
```

"query/segmentAndCache/time" overwrites the default value

most places overwrite it except in the plumber

we should force overwrite
@himanshug shoudl we backport this bug?
@fjy i don't think many people actually use nested-groupBy queries, because this bug has been able to exist until now. that said, no harm in backporting so will do once merged.
@nishantmonu51 always turning it on sounds fine to me
Thanks for the PR @sascha-coenen ! Do you mind filling out http://druid.io/community/cla.html ?
@nicktylah I think this is pretty close to ready to merge in. Can you move the setRegion call (if a region is specified) into the AmazonEC2 provider method? After that I think we're good.

Is there anything in the AWS docs that points to this constraint?

Either way can the constraint be enforced in the EC2IamProfileData constructor instead of so late in the data usage cycle?

I don't think we should be removing name completely from the profile.
Looks related to https://github.com/hamidnazari/amibaker/issues/14
@nishantmonu51 any more comments?
@bjozet last comment, can we squash commits? after that I will merge
@rasahner can you +1 this if you think it is ready?

@rpashuto we have some backlog preventing us from reviewing this in detail

Do you know if it is possible to actually restructure this code as a module to Druid? If so, it'll be much faster review process

Why not just store

```
{
  'timestamp'='2016-01-01 ~~',
  'lot_id'='xxxx',
  'machine_id'='yyyy',
  'p'=['pkey1=value1', 'pkey2=value2']
}
```

?

Or, more better would be to actually support map-style columns.  Do you need this to be a dimension?  If you don't need it to be a dimension, you should already be able to model this as a complex "metric" column.

@cheddar Yes, basically it's possible in any way. This is just a syntactic sugar for easing access to the values. In client side which is mostly a UI server in our use case, parsing the list values or adding dim filter to acquire wanted value would not be welcomed by UI developers. They just want a map and access values like that. And size of this map can be >1000 and it would be good to use bitmap, which is not possible with current complex metric.
@navis no worries, i understood what you are trying to do after reading the code. Hope to get this merged soon.
@drcrallen @himanshug @gianm can u guys review?

I have added a reference to the `metadata-init` tool, however I am not sure if it works.
If someone can answer my question on google groups, i am happy to update the docs with it:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/iYB2nSFZYoI

@pdeva This is actually not the tool I was talking about. I was talking about [insert-segment-to-db](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/services/src/main/java/io/druid/cli/InsertSegment.java), see [Insert Segment to DB](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/docs/content/operations/insert-segment-to-db.md)
@fjy this is an incompatible operations change since it will beak pull-deps in any build processes until the coordinates are updated. As such do we need to backport this to 0.9.0?

I'm torn because on one hand it is a straight forward coordinate change, but on the other hand it will break build processes immediately after we have a build-process breaking release, which is not good.

In truth, I think this PR made more sense when `setRegion` was called in the constructor of `EC2Autoscaler` -- and I can't imagine a problem with thread safety since that line should (as far as I can tell) always run before any usage of the `amazonEC2Client` in the `EC2Autoscaler`.

I looked into it a bit and the setting needed is really far removed from where it needs to be set (in the constructor for the client). And having a region is not an autoscaler specific thing, which is I think where the muddling comes in.

Would it solve your use case if the EC2 client config was the same for everyone in the global EC2 client?

I think it makes total sense for the region to be set in the provider method (`AWSModule`). It's unfortunate that the region config itself is tucked so far away in the indexing service package. If I could find the binding for the `EC2EnvironmentConfig` and play around with that I'm sure I could set it correctly, I'm just struggling to get that piece of information.
I haven't been able to find any documentation (even in the source code), but happy to move it higher up.

@navis thanks for addressing the comments. they seem to be fine now. 
I think this is ready to go. :+1:
cool, thanks so much. I signed the CLA and sent it to the druid-admin email address just now.

@fjy 
As I see it,the hydrant that was swapped without being replaced must be the last hydrant in the sink,and this sink already merged.Because if execute persist() always execute sink.swap method to replace first,Only During the merge and push operation ,skip executing sink.swap method,directly execute persistHydrant() method.
It must be said,I don't deploy official release version,In order to do as much as possible not to drop message,change the code of NoopRejectionPolicyFactory base on 0.8.2.

If  add the message before the window period to the sink causes this behavior.
Found following message in the log

> 2016-02-27 01:03:00,215 INFO i.d.s.r.p.RealtimePlumber [dsp_report_access_day-2016-02-26T23:00:00.000+08:00-persist-n-merge] Hydrant[FireHydrant{index=io.druid.segment.incremental.OnheapIncrementalIndex@11c39f36, queryable=io.druid.segment.ReferenceCountingSegment@42099b56, count=59}] hasn't swapped yet, swapping. Sink[Sink{interval=2016-02-26T23:00:00.000+08:00/2016-02-27T00:00:00.000+08:00, schema=DataSchema{dataSource='dsp_report_access_day', parser={parseSpec={format=tsv, listDelimiter=|, timestampSpec={column=timestamp, format=millis}, columns=[timestamp, position, sell_position, p_count], dimensionsSpec={dimensions=[position, sell_position], dimensionExclusions=[]}}}, aggregators=[LongSumAggregatorFactory{fieldName='p_count', name='count'}], granularitySpec=io.druid.segment.indexing.granularity.UniformGranularitySpec@7e4cd909}}]

I think it is useful.

@binlijin can you please
1. add documentation 
2. add UTs at least ser deser
3. explain how this sort of solve the two issues you have mentioned above ?

Thanks !
@fjy squashed and ready to go. I shamelessly stole @gianm's comment from this thread for commit message.
@fjy I'll try to do that
@himanshug any benchmarks ?

@b-slim it can only improve performance for various cases. improvement will largely depend upon the size of intermediate groupBy result sets. More the number of dimensions and rows to be put in IncrementalIndex better the performace would be.

various benchmarks for sorted vs un-sorted maps can be seen at http://www.mapdb.org/benchmarks.html . they have direct relevance here. performance difference in "Random Updates" should be noted.

@fjy @drcrallen I guess we can continue to keep distributing "community extensions" as well and then there wouldn't be a build process break.
Difference between "community" vs "core" extension would largely be a difference in terms of  user expectation with respect to maintenance and potential correctness of the extension.

@himanshug thanks, just to clarify, my question was for the sake of learning. In fact i thought that by contract `queryRunner` returns an order-timed sequence as indicated [here](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/18479bb757029c4878211da3a2297fd68c8c158b/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/query/QueryRunner.java#L31-L31). And based on that thought that `mergeRunners` can use that ordered property to do the merge.
@b-slim gpBy merging happens by storing whole result sets in IncrementalIndex and which does not depend upon ordered input.
@himanshug That's how I see it, and the reason for keeping them in the main druid repository is so that future core changes have a better idea for how wide-spread the extension impact is.
Yep got it, thanks!

IMHO if the api still supports `name` and we had the config option there previously, we should not get rid of it. Making the constructor for the class depend on only one or the other being set is reasonable.
